Award.AwardTitle: Nanofabrication, Characterization, and Analysis of Topological Insulator Nanostructures

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this program is to create nanoelectronic devices made from topological insulator nanostructures and explore new areas for creating and characterizing
low-dissipation electronics. In particular, the PIs intend to address the following aims: (i) fabricating transistors based on topological insulator nanoribbons and nanojunctions by using template-mediated growth; (ii) characterizing the magnetotransport and thermoelectric properties of topological insulator devices by using torque magnetometry and capacitance spectroscopy; and (iii) achieving an in-depth understanding of experimental results through theoretical modeling.

The intellectual merit is that the successful completion of the proposed research can transform the basis of future transistors with low power consumption and enable reconfigurable topological quantum computation. Particularly, the fundamental science associated with the modulation of topological surface states via external fields will be studied allowing for the realization of electronic operations involving reversible switching of topological states. The performance of the proposed new topological transistor devices would surpass that of conventional silicon based devices, in terms of the higher speed (~1 THz) and the lower power consumption (microwatt).

The broader impacts are extending nanoelectronics education opportunities for students from high schools and universities. All the PIs are involved in education and outreach programs; including a collaboration with The University of Michigan's academic programs to provide research opportunities for undergraduate students, as well as a collaboration with Lurie Nanofabrication Facility in outreach workshops for K-12 educators, workshops for the Michigan Science Teacher Association conference, and the "NanoCamps" program sponsored by National Science Foundation.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This NSF-funded project aimed to create nanoelectronic devices made from topological insulator nanostructures and explore new areas for creating and characterizing low-dissipation electronics. In particular, the project sought to address the following objectives: (a) fabricating transistors based on topological insulator nanoribbons and nanojunctions by using template-mediated growth; (b) characterizing the magnetotransport and thermoelectric properties of topological insulator devices by using torque magnetometry and capacitance spectroscopy; and (c) achieving an in-depth understanding of experimental results through theoretical modeling. In the 3 years of the award, the research team has made significant breakthroughs in developing new methods of growing characterizing and modeling the electronic structures of topological nanoscale materials. Specifically, the research project has resulted in the following outcomes: (1) Discover of the first correlated topological insulator. In this material samarium hexaboride (SmB6) the strong coupling between electrons make the material a preface. By contrast, due to its special topological natures of the electronic structure, the material surfaces turn to good materials. The team predicted and experimental confirmed the topological insulator nature of SmB6. (2). New methods of growing topological insulator nanodevicees. The team developed a new systematic chemical vapor deposition method for improving the total yield of sub-100 nm wide topological insulator bismuth selenide nanoribbons. The new growth can be realized on various substrate, including two-dimensional (2D) layered semiconductors.  They invented also developed a new plasma-assisted doping approach for tuning the electronic bands as well as Fermi levels in topological insulators and other 2D nanoelectronic materials. (3) Novel characterization techniques for topological materials. The research them developed ultra-sensitive torque magnetometers and miniature capacitance-based thermal transport techniques to resolve the electronic and phonon structures of new solid state materials. (4) Theoretical mapping of fractional topological states. The research team revealed the deep and fundamental connection between these novel fractional states and fractional quantum Hall multi-layers.

 

Intellectual Merit:  The successful completion of the proposed research can transform the basis of future transistors with low power consumption and enable reconfigurable topological quantum computation. Particularly, the fundamental science associated with the modulation of topological surface states via external fields will be studied allowing for the realization of electronic operations involving reversible switching of topological states. The performance of the proposed new topological transistor devices would surpass that of conventional silicon based devices, in terms of the higher speed and the lower power consumption (microwatt). The integration of topological insulator nano/micro-structures with other emerging 2D layered materials can create new power­switching and energy­conversion devices with innovative operation schemes. The knowledge acquired from the study of such devices broadly impacts the fields related to electronics, optoelectronics, and photonics.

 

Broader Impact: This work extends science and engineering education opportunities for students from high schools and universities. The research has attracted 7 graduate students, and 18 undergraduate students working in the cutting edge research fields of nanoelectronic and topological materials. As a result, the project initiated five thesis works of 5 Ph.D. students. Among these undergraduate students, more than half continued in graduate school education in the STEM fields in top universities, such as Stanford University, Caltech, and the University of Michigan. The project also leads to a number of exciting outreach programs; including public lectures to the general public through the “Saturday Morning Physics” lecture series, a collaboration with The University of Michigan's academic programs to provide research opportunities for undergraduate students, as well as a collaboration with Lurie Nanofabrication Facility in outreach workshops for K-12 educators, workshops for the Michigan Science Teacher Association conference, and the “NanoCamps” program sponsored by National Science Foundation.
